page.title: 10 THE COOMBE HILL CANAL 2
page.content: The tow path makes an excellent footpath to see the water meadows. As these are flooded regularly, the farmers cannot use them in winter for grazing and cannot use fertilisers with the result that true meadow grass grows in them with lots of wild meadow flowers. Instead of being green, they have a bufff coloured appearance with lots of yellow and white flower heads and patches of red poppies. On the slightly higher meadows, the colour was all green where fertilisers are used and the farmers were cutting silage and hay. The fields are divided by hedges and many drainage ditches. In winter many duck, geese and migratory birds are to be seen in this area. The Coombe Hill Canal was abandoned in 1876.
